questions.question: What is an electromagnet?
options: A. A permanent magnet made of iron
B. A magnet in which magnetic field is produced through electric current
C. A magnet that works without electricity
D. A natural magnet found in earth
questions.correct_answer: B. A magnet in which magnetic field is produced through electric current
questions.explanation: An electromagnet is a type of magnet in which a magnetic field is produced through electric current.

questions.question: What is the branch of physics that deals with magnetic effect of electric current called?
questions.explanation: The branch of physics which deals with the magnetic effect of electric current is called electromagnetism.

questions.question: What is the core of an electromagnet made of?
questions.explanation: An electromagnet consists of a soft iron piece, called the core, on which an insulated copper wire is wound.

questions.question: What happens to an electromagnet when the electric current is stopped?
options: D. It becomes a permanent magnet
questions.explanation: As soon as the current is stopped, the soft iron core loses its magnetism because an electromagnet is a temporary magnet.

questions.question: An electromagnet is an example of which type of magnet?
questions.explanation: Electromagnets are examples of temporary magnets as they retain magnetism only when current flows through them.

questions.question: Permanent magnets are usually made of which type of materials?
questions.explanation: Permanent magnets are usually made of hard materials while temporary magnets are made of soft materials.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a permanent magnet?
questions.explanation: Examples of permanent magnets are bar magnets and horse-shoe magnets.

questions.question: How many types of electromagnets are there based on shape?
questions.explanation: Depending on the shape of the magnet, electromagnets are of two types - bar-shaped and U-shaped magnets.

questions.question: In a bar-shaped electromagnet, the insulated copper wire is wrapped around what?
questions.explanation: In a bar-shaped electromagnet, an insulated copper wire is wrapped around a bar-shaped soft iron core.

questions.question: The end of an electromagnet where current flows in clockwise direction acts as which pole?
questions.explanation: The end of the electromagnet where the current flows in a clockwise direction acts as the south pole.

questions.question: The end of an electromagnet where current flows in anticlockwise direction acts as which pole?
questions.explanation: The end where the current flows in the anticlockwise direction acts as the north pole.

questions.question: In the electromagnet activity, what material is used as the core?
questions.explanation: In the activity to make an electromagnet, an iron nail is used as the core.

questions.question: What is observed when paper clips are brought near an electromagnet with current flowing through it?
options: B. Paper clips are attracted at the ends
questions.correct_answer: B. Paper clips are attracted at the ends
questions.explanation: The iron nail attracts the paper clips at its ends when current flows through the coil.

questions.question: What happens to the strength of an electromagnet when the current flowing through the coil increases?
questions.explanation: As the amount of current flowing through the coil increases, the electromagnet becomes stronger.

questions.question: The strength of an electromagnet is directly proportional to:
options: A. Only current flowing through it
B. Only number of turns of coil
C. Both current and number of turns
D. Neither current nor number of turns
questions.correct_answer: C. Both current and number of turns
questions.explanation: The strength of an electromagnet is directly proportional to both the amount of electric current and the number of turns per unit length of the coil.

questions.question: If the number of turns per unit length of the coil is less, what type of electromagnet is obtained?
questions.explanation: If the number of turns per unit length of the coil are less, a weak electromagnet is obtained.

questions.question: Electromagnets are used in which of the following?
questions.explanation: Electromagnets are used in electric bells, cranes to lift heavy loads, and bullet trains.

questions.question: Electromagnets are used in cranes to lift:
questions.explanation: Electromagnets are used in cranes to lift heavy loads of scrap iron and steel.

questions.question: In medicine, electromagnets are used for:
options: B. Removing steel splinters from wounds
questions.correct_answer: B. Removing steel splinters from wounds
questions.explanation: Electromagnets are used for removing steel splinters from patient's wounds and to cure other ailments.

questions.question: Which component of an electric bell gets magnetised when current flows through it?
questions.explanation: When current flows through the U-shaped electromagnet, it gets magnetised and attracts the armature.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.question: An electric bell consists of all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: An electric bell consists of an electromagnet, contact spring, contact screw, armature, hammer and gong. It does not contain a permanent magnet.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.question: What material is the armature in an electric bell made of?
questions.explanation: The electromagnet attracts the armature made of iron towards itself.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.question: What produces the sound in an electric bell?
questions.explanation: The hammer attached to the armature hits the gong and sound (bell ring) is produced.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.question: What pulls the armature back to its original position in an electric bell?
questions.explanation: The spring pulls the armature back to its original position when the circuit breaks.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.question: What is electromagnetic induction?
options: A. Producing magnetic field from current
B. Producing current from changing magnetic field
questions.correct_answer: B. Producing current from changing magnetic field
questions.explanation: Electromagnetic induction is the phenomenon of producing an electric current in a conductor due to change in the magnetic lines of force.

questions.question: The current produced by electromagnetic induction is called:
questions.explanation: The current produced by electromagnetic induction is called induced current.

questions.question: What type of wire is wound around the core of an electromagnet?
questions.explanation: An insulated copper wire is wound in a coil around the soft iron core.

questions.question: Why do temporary magnets behave as magnets only in presence of a magnetic field?
options: A. They are made of hard materials
B. They are made of soft materials
questions.correct_answer: B. They are made of soft materials
questions.explanation: Temporary magnets are usually made of soft materials and behave as magnets only in the presence of a strong magnetic field.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a use of electromagnets?
questions.explanation: Electromagnets are used in audio/video tapes, preparing permanent magnets, and separating iron ore, but not for generating solar energy.

questions.question: What happens when the push button of an electric bell is released?
questions.explanation: The whole sequence of the hammer hitting the gong is repeated as long as the push button switch is kept pressed. When released, it stops.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.question: On what type of board are the components of an electric bell fitted?
questions.explanation: The components of an electric bell are fitted on a flat wooden or plastic board.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.question: The myth that we can get a magnet with a single pole is:
questions.explanation: Some magnets are sold labelled as single pole but they actually have both poles - one is just covered with adhesive or surrounded by a plastic or metal cup.

questions.question: Horse-shoe magnet is an example of:
questions.explanation: Examples of permanent magnets are bar magnets and horse-shoe magnets.

questions.question: In an electric bell, what breaks the circuit?
options: B. The displacement of armature from contact screw
questions.correct_answer: B. The displacement of armature from contact screw
questions.explanation: Due to the displacement of the armature from its original position, it loses contact with the contact screw. This breaks the circuit.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.question: Electromagnets are used in loading furnaces with:
questions.explanation: Electromagnets are used in loading furnaces with iron.

questions.question: What retains magnetism only when electric current passes through it?
questions.explanation: An electromagnet is a temporary magnet which retains the property of magnetism only when an electric current is passed through it.

questions.question: How can the strength of an electromagnet be increased?
options: B. By decreasing number of turns
C. By increasing number of turns
questions.correct_answer: C. By increasing number of turns
questions.explanation: On increasing the number of turns of the coil, the strength of the electromagnet can be increased.

questions.question: The terminals of an electric bell are labelled as:
questions.explanation: The terminals T1 and T2 of the bell are connected to a battery through a push button switch.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.question: What is required for electromagnetic induction to occur?
options: B. Change in magnetic lines of force
questions.correct_answer: B. Change in magnetic lines of force
questions.explanation: Electromagnetic induction occurs due to change in the magnetic lines of force associated with the conductor.

questions.question: In the activity to make an electromagnet, what is removed from both ends of the copper wire?
questions.explanation: Remove the plastic coating from both the ends of the copper wire before wrapping it around the iron nail.

questions.question: Which instrument is used to detect electric current in an electric circuit?
questions.explanation: A galvanometer is used to detect the presence and direction of electric current in a circuit.

questions.question: Who discovered electromagnetic induction?
questions.explanation: Michael Faraday discovered electromagnetic induction in 1831.

questions.question: What is essential for electromagnetic induction to occur between a magnet and a conductor?
options: C. Only the conductor should move
D. Only the magnet should move
questions.explanation: For electromagnetic induction, there must be relative motion between the magnet and the conductor.

questions.question: Which part of an electric bell continuously makes and breaks the circuit?
questions.explanation: The armature moving away from and back to the contact screw creates the make-and-break mechanism.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.question: What type of core does a U-shaped electromagnet have?
questions.explanation: In a U-shaped electromagnet, an insulated copper wire is wrapped around a U-shaped soft iron core.

questions.question: Why is soft iron preferred over steel for making electromagnet cores?
options: B. Soft iron loses magnetism quickly when current stops
C. Steel is harder to shape
D. Soft iron is more magnetic permanently
questions.correct_answer: B. Soft iron loses magnetism quickly when current stops
questions.explanation: Soft iron loses its magnetism quickly when current is stopped, making it ideal for temporary magnets.

questions.question: In an electric bell, what component is attached to the hammer?
questions.explanation: The hammer is attached to the armature, so when the armature moves, the hammer strikes the gong.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.question: Bullet trains use electromagnets for:
questions.explanation: Bullet trains (maglev trains) use electromagnets for magnetic levitation to reduce friction.

questions.question: What happens to the magnetic field when current through an electromagnet is doubled?
questions.explanation: The strength of an electromagnet is directly proportional to current, so doubling current doubles the magnetic strength.

questions.question: Which scientist's work on electromagnetic induction led to the development of electric generators?
questions.explanation: Michael Faraday's discovery of electromagnetic induction led to the development of electric generators and transformers.

questions.question: In an electric bell, current flows from T1 through the electromagnet, then through:
options: B. The contact screw to T2
questions.correct_answer: B. The contact screw to T2
questions.explanation: Current flows from battery to electromagnet, then to contact screw, and finally to T2 and back to battery.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.question: What happens if the number of turns in an electromagnet coil is halved?
questions.explanation: The strength is directly proportional to the number of turns, so halving turns halves the strength.

questions.question: Audio and video tapes use electromagnets for:
options: B. Recording and reading magnetic data
questions.correct_answer: B. Recording and reading magnetic data
questions.explanation: Electromagnets are used in audio and video tapes for recording and reading magnetic data.

questions.question: What converts chemical energy to electrical energy when connected to an electromagnet?
questions.explanation: A battery converts chemical energy to electrical energy which powers the electromagnet.

questions.question: In the activity with iron nail, what confirms that it has become an electromagnet?
questions.explanation: The iron nail attracting paper clips at its ends confirms it has become an electromagnet.

questions.question: Which of the following does NOT affect the strength of an electromagnet?
questions.explanation: The color of the wire does not affect electromagnet strength; current, turns, and core material do.

questions.question: Electromagnets are used in hospitals for:
options: B. MRI machines and removing metal from wounds
questions.correct_answer: B. MRI machines and removing metal from wounds
questions.explanation: Electromagnets are used to remove steel splinters from wounds and in MRI machines.

questions.question: If both the magnet and conductor are stationary, what is the induced current?
questions.explanation: Without relative motion between magnet and conductor, no change in magnetic flux occurs, so induced current is zero.

questions.question: The contact spring in an electric bell helps to:
options: B. Restore armature to original position
questions.correct_answer: B. Restore armature to original position
questions.explanation: The spring pulls the armature back to its original position when the circuit breaks.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.question: What material are the coil windings of an electromagnet typically made of?
questions.explanation: Insulated copper wire is used for the coil windings as copper is an excellent conductor.

questions.question: Permanent magnets retain their magnetism because they are made of:
questions.explanation: Permanent magnets are made of hard materials that retain their magnetic alignment.

questions.question: In iron ore separation, electromagnets attract:
questions.explanation: Electromagnets are used to separate iron ore from impurities by attracting iron and its compounds.

questions.question: What is the shape of the electromagnet used in an electric bell?
questions.explanation: A U-shaped electromagnet is used in an electric bell.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.question: Which of the following correctly describes electromagnetic induction?
questions.explanation: Electromagnetic induction is the phenomenon where changing magnetic field produces electric current.

questions.question: Why is the copper wire in an electromagnet insulated?
options: B. To prevent short circuits between turns
questions.correct_answer: B. To prevent short circuits between turns
questions.explanation: Insulation prevents short circuits between adjacent turns of the coil, ensuring current flows through all turns.

questions.question: What converts mechanical energy to electrical energy using electromagnetic induction?
questions.explanation: A generator converts mechanical energy to electrical energy using the principle of electromagnetic induction.

questions.question: When an electromagnet is switched off, the soft iron core:
questions.explanation: Soft iron loses its magnetism instantly when current is switched off.

questions.question: What causes the hammer to strike repeatedly in an electric bell?
questions.explanation: The make-and-break mechanism caused by armature movement creates repeated hammer strikes.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.question: Electromagnets can be controlled by:
options: B. Switching current on and off
questions.correct_answer: B. Switching current on and off
questions.explanation: Electromagnets can be easily controlled by turning current on or off, unlike permanent magnets.

questions.question: A magnet labelled as 'north pole only' actually:
options: B. Has both poles with south pole covered
D. Is not a real magnet
questions.correct_answer: B. Has both poles with south pole covered
questions.explanation: Such magnets have both poles but one is covered with adhesive, plastic, or metal cup.

questions.question: The unit length in 'number of turns per unit length' typically refers to:
questions.explanation: Number of turns per unit length refers to how many turns are wound per unit length of the core.

questions.question: Electric motors work on the principle opposite to:
questions.explanation: Motors convert electrical energy to mechanical energy, opposite to generators which use electromagnetic induction.

questions.question: Which component connects the battery to the bell circuit?
questions.explanation: The push button switch connects the battery to the bell circuit when pressed.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.question: Electromagnets are preferred in cranes over permanent magnets because:
options: B. They can be switched off to release load
questions.correct_answer: B. They can be switched off to release load
questions.explanation: Electromagnets can be switched off to release the scrap metal, which permanent magnets cannot do easily.

questions.question: The brass cap in a dry cell is connected to which electrode in an electromagnet circuit?
questions.explanation: The brass cap of a dry cell is the positive terminal connected to one end of the electromagnet coil.

questions.question: In the electromagnet activity, the wire is wrapped tightly to:
questions.explanation: Wrapping wire tightly ensures maximum turns per unit length, increasing magnetic strength.

questions.question: What type of current flows through household electric bells?
questions.explanation: Most household electric bells operate on direct current from batteries or transformers.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.question: Faraday's experiments on electromagnetic induction were performed in:
questions.explanation: Michael Faraday discovered electromagnetic induction through his experiments in 1831.

questions.question: Which property allows soft iron to be used as an electromagnet core?
questions.explanation: Soft iron has low retentivity, meaning it loses magnetism quickly when current stops.

questions.question: The gong in an electric bell is made of:
questions.explanation: The gong is made of metal to produce a clear ringing sound when struck by the hammer.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.question: An electromagnet can attract:
options: B. Only magnetic materials like iron
questions.correct_answer: B. Only magnetic materials like iron
questions.explanation: Electromagnets attract magnetic materials like iron, steel, nickel, and cobalt.

questions.question: The phenomenon where electric current produces magnetic field is called:
questions.explanation: Electromagnetism is the branch dealing with magnetic effects of electric current.

questions.question: Which device uses electromagnetic induction to work?
questions.explanation: Transformers use electromagnetic induction to change voltage levels.

questions.question: The strength of magnetic field inside an electromagnet is:
questions.explanation: The magnetic field is strongest at the poles of an electromagnet.

questions.question: In industrial applications, electromagnets are used for:
options: A. Separating magnetic from non-magnetic materials
questions.correct_answer: A. Separating magnetic from non-magnetic materials
questions.explanation: Electromagnets separate iron ore from impurities and scrap metal from waste.

questions.question: What determines the polarity (north or south) of an electromagnet's end?
questions.explanation: Clockwise current creates south pole; anticlockwise current creates north pole.

questions.question: Electric telephones use electromagnets in their:
questions.explanation: Electromagnets are used in telephone speakers and microphones to convert electrical signals to sound and vice versa.

questions.question: If current direction in an electromagnet is reversed, the:
questions.explanation: Reversing current direction reverses the direction of current flow at each end, swapping the poles.

questions.question: The working principle of a generator is:
questions.explanation: Generators work on electromagnetic induction where changing magnetic field produces current.

questions.question: An electromagnet loses its magnetism when current stops because:
options: B. Core is made of soft material with low retentivity
questions.correct_answer: B. Core is made of soft material with low retentivity
questions.explanation: The soft iron core has low retentivity and cannot retain magnetism without current.

questions.question: How many terminals does an electric bell have?
questions.explanation: An electric bell has two terminals, T1 and T2, for connecting to the power source.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.question: Which of the following increases when coil turns are closely wound?
options: B. Number of turns per unit length
questions.correct_answer: B. Number of turns per unit length
questions.explanation: Closely wound coils have more turns per unit length, increasing magnetic strength.

questions.question: The contact screw in an electric bell is made of:
questions.explanation: The contact screw is made of metal to conduct electricity when touching the armature.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.question: Permanent magnets cannot be used in cranes because they:
options: B. Cannot be switched off to release load
questions.correct_answer: B. Cannot be switched off to release load
questions.explanation: Permanent magnets cannot be easily switched off to release the attracted load.

questions.question: The induced current in a conductor depends on:
options: B. Rate of change of magnetic flux
questions.correct_answer: B. Rate of change of magnetic flux
questions.explanation: Faster change in magnetic flux produces greater induced current.

questions.question: What is used to connect the wire ends to battery terminals in the electromagnet activity?
questions.explanation: Tape is used to secure the wire ends to the battery terminals.

questions.question: Which type of electromagnet has two poles at the same end?
questions.explanation: U-shaped electromagnets have both poles (ends of the U) on the same side, making them more useful for attracting objects.

questions.question: Electromagnets are used in which medical imaging technique?
questions.explanation: MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) uses powerful electromagnets to create images of body organs.

questions.question: What happens to paper clips near an electromagnet when the switch is turned off?
questions.explanation: When current stops, the electromagnet loses its magnetism and releases the paper clips.

questions.question: The reason an electromagnet activity is called 'not a fair test' is because:
options: B. Control experiment (testing nail without current) was not done
D. Too many clips were used
questions.correct_answer: B. Control experiment (testing nail without current) was not done
questions.explanation: A fair test requires comparing with a control - testing if the nail alone (without current) picks up clips.
